definition: to offer advice/to make a suggestion
to offer/to present/to dedicate/to donate/to show/to put on display/worthy person (old)

policy/plan/scheme/bamboo slip for writing (old)/to whip (a horse)/to encourage/riding crop with sharp spines (old)/essay written for the imperial examinations (old)/upward horizontal stroke in calligraphy
surname Ce

sentences.english: We brainstormed for most of the afternoon.
sentences.chinese: 下午的大部分時間我們都在開獻策攻關會。

sentences.english: I had a private audience with the King, and made a proposition.
sentences.chinese: 我私下朝見國王，向他陳言獻策。

sentences.english: She was never behind in offering advice.
sentences.chinese: 她在出諫言獻策方面從不落於人後。

sentences.english: They contribute to business strategy, and they transform that strategy through technology.
sentences.chinese: 他們爲業務戰略獻計獻策，通過技術改變這個戰略。

sentences.english: Various media to the new Chairman, Mr Guo "suggestions".
sentences.chinese: 各路媒體紛紛向新任主席郭樹清“建言獻策”。

sentences.english: To enable students to broaden their horizons, for the company's long-term development suggestions.
sentences.chinese: 使學員開拓視野，爲公司的長遠發展獻計獻策。

sentences.english: Vote on the traffickers , the masses have a lot of wisdom to offer advice and suggestions.
sentences.chinese: 就票販子的情況，羣衆也有無窮的智慧來獻計獻策。
他爲這個計劃獻計獻策。

sentences.english: Provide advice to Department manager to manage their teams.
sentences.chinese: 就團隊管理事宜爲各部門經理建言獻策。

sentences.english: Kim hoped that people from all walks of life would, through the forum, produce good ideas for the prosperity of Asia.
sentences.chinese: 他希望各界人士能通過論壇爲亞洲的繁榮獻計獻策。

definition: to offer advice/to make a suggestion
to discuss politics
neighborly relations
to judge the hour and size up the situation/to take stock
to be at the highest level of enlightenment (Buddhist expression)
grand event/magnificent undertaking
retort with challenging questions/debate
the press/the media
to take turns/to work by roster
to run a newspaper/to publish a newspaper
to conspire/to plot (a rebellion, crime etc)/to machinate/to spur on/to urge action
state policy
civil society
political relations
to be in overall charge/to oversee
(Tw) to draw on (others' experience)/to learn from (how others do things)/lesson to be learned (by observing others)
